docs.title: fpstreams
docs.text:
A robust, type-safe functional programming library for Python.

fpstreams brings the power of Java Streams, Rust Results, and JavaScript Array methods to Python. It provides a fluent interface for data processing, null safety, and error handling without the boilerplate, all while remaining fully typed for IDE autocompletion.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Fluent Streams: Lazy evaluation chains (map, filter, reduce, zip)
  • Null Safety: Option monad to eliminate None checks.
  • Error Handling: Result monad (Success/Failure) to replace ugly try/except blocks.
  • Powerful Collectors: Grouping, partitioning, and joining made simple.
  • Functional Tools: Utilities like pipe and curry for cleaner composition.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pip install fpstreams

Comparison between standard streams and fpstreams.parallel() on a 4-core machine:

Task Sequential Parallel Speedup Heavy Calculation (Factorials) 21.10s 8.25s 2.56x I/O Simulation (Requests) 2.08s 0.73s 2.87x

Note: Parallelism has overhead. Use .parallel() only for computationally intensive tasks or large datasets.

docs.title: Streams (using name from Java)
docs.text:
from fpstreams import Stream

data = [
    {"name": "Alice", "role": "admin", "age": 30},
    {"name": "Bob", "role": "dev", "age": 25},
    {"name": "Charlie", "role": "admin", "age": 45}
]

# Get names of admins whose age is over 25, sorted alphabetically
names = (
    Stream(data)
    .filter(lambda u: u["role"] == "admin")
    .filter(lambda u: u["age"] > 25)
    .map(lambda u: u["name"].upper())
    .sorted()
    .to_list()
)
# Output: ['ALICE', 'CHARLIE']

docs.title: Null Safety with Option
docs.text:
from fpstreams import Stream

# Find the first user named "Steven" (who doesn't exist)
email = (
    Stream(data)
    .filter(lambda u: u["name"] == "Steven")
    .find_first()               # Returns Option[User]
    .map(lambda u: u["email"])  # Skipped because Option is empty
    .or_else("default@example.com")
)

docs.title: Error handling with Result
docs.text:
from fpstreams import Result

def risky_parsing(value):
    return int(value) # Might crash if value is not a number

# Safe execution
result = (
    Result.of(lambda: risky_parsing("invalid"))
    .map(lambda x: x * 2)
    .on_failure(lambda e: print(f"Parsing failed: {e}")) # Logs error
    .get_or_else(0) # Returns 0 instead of crashing
)

docs.title: Collectors
docs.text:
grouping data using collectors

from fpstreams import Stream, Collectors

fruits = ["apple", "avocado", "banana", "blueberry", "cherry"]

# Group fruits by their first letter
grouped = (
    Stream(fruits)
    .collect(Collectors.grouping_by(lambda s: s[0]))
)
# Output: {'a': ['apple', 'avocado'], 'b': ['banana', 'blueberry'], 'c': ['cherry']}

docs.title: Infinite Streams & Lazy Evaluation
docs.text:
Process massive datasets efficiently. Operations are only executed when needed.

def infinite_counter():
    n = 0
    while True:
        yield n
        n += 1

# Take only the first 10 even numbers
evens = (
    Stream(infinite_counter())
    .filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
    .limit(10)
    .to_list()
)

docs.title: Parallel Processing
docs.text:
fpstreams can automatically distribute heavy workloads across all CPU cores using the .parallel() method. It uses an optimized Map-Reduce architecture to minimize memory usage.

from fpstreams import Stream

def heavy_task(x):
    return x ** 5000

# Automatically uses all available CPU cores
results = (
    Stream(range(10000))
    .parallel()
    .map(heavy_task)
    .to_list()
)

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
• Stream: The core wrapper for sequential data processing.
  • ParallelStream: A multi-core wrapper for heavy parallel processing.
  • Option: A monad container for optional values (Null Safety).
  • Result: A monad container for operations that may fail (Error Handling).
  • Collectors: Helper functions for aggregation (e.g., grouping_by, partitioning_by).
  • functional: Utilities like pipe and curry for functional composition.

docs.title: Collectors API
docs.text: The Collectors class provides common reduction operations for Stream.collect().

docs.title: to_list() staticmethod
docs.text: Collects elements into a List.

docs.title: to_set() staticmethod
docs.text: Collects elements into a Set.

docs.title: counting() staticmethod
docs.text: Counts the number of elements.

docs.title: joining(delimiter='') staticmethod
docs.text: Joins string elements.

docs.title: grouping_by(key_mapper) staticmethod
docs.text: Groups elements by a classification function. Example: Stream(["apple", "ant"]).collect(grouping_by(lambda s: s[0])) Result: {'a': ['apple', 'ant']}

docs.title: to_dict(key_mapper, value_mapper) staticmethod
docs.text: Collects elements into a Dictionary. Example: Stream(users).collect(to_dict(lambda u: u.id, lambda u: u.name))

docs.title: partitioning_by(predicate) staticmethod
docs.text: Partitions elements into two lists based on a predicate. Returns a dict: {True: [matches], False: [non-matches]}

docs.title: to_columns() staticmethod
docs.text: Transposes a list of dicts into a dict of lists. Handles missing keys by inserting None to ensure alignment.

docs.title: Functional Utilities
docs.text: Helper functions for functional composition and currying.

docs.title: curry(func)
docs.text:
Transforms a function that takes multiple arguments into a chain of functions. @curry def add(a, b): return a + b

add(1)(2) # returns 3

Source code in src\fpstreams\functional.py 
def curry(func: Callable) -> Callable:
    """
    Transforms a function that takes multiple arguments into a chain of functions.
    @curry
    def add(a, b): return a + b

    add(1)(2) # returns 3
    """
    @functools.wraps(func)
    def curried(*args):
        if len(args) >= func.__code__.co_argcount:
            return func(*args)
        return lambda *more: curried(*(args + more))
    return curried

docs.title: pipe(value, *functions)
docs.text:
Passes a value through a sequence of functions. pipe(x, f, g, h) is equivalent to h(g(f(x)))

Source code in src\fpstreams\functional.py 
def pipe(value: T, *functions: Callable[[Any], Any]) -> Any: # type: ignore
    """
    Passes a value through a sequence of functions.
    pipe(x, f, g, h) is equivalent to h(g(f(x)))
    """
    return functools.reduce(lambda val, func: func(val), functions, value)

docs.title: fpstreams.Option
docs.text:
Bases: Generic[T]

A container object which may or may not contain a non-null value. Replaces None checks.

docs.title: empty() classmethod
docs.text: Returns an empty Option instance.

docs.title: filter(predicate)
docs.text: If a value is present and matches the given predicate, return an Option describing the value, otherwise return an empty Option.

docs.title: flat_map(mapper)
docs.text: If a value is present, apply the provided Option-bearing mapping function to it, return that result, otherwise return an empty Option.

docs.title: if_present(action)
docs.text: If a value is present, invokes the specified consumer with the value, otherwise does nothing.

docs.title: is_empty()
docs.text: Returns True if there is no value present, otherwise False.

docs.title: is_present()
docs.text: Returns True if there is a value present, otherwise False.

docs.title: map(mapper)
docs.text: If a value is present, apply the provided mapping function to it, and if the result is non-null, return an Option describing the result.

docs.title: of(value) classmethod
docs.text: Returns an Option describing the given non-null value.

docs.title: of_nullable(value) classmethod
docs.text: Returns an Option describing the given value, if non-null, otherwise returns an empty Option.

docs.title: or_else(other)
docs.text: Return the value if present, otherwise return other.

docs.title: or_else_get(supplier)
docs.text: Return the value if present, otherwise invoke other and return the result of that invocation.

docs.title: or_else_throw(exception_supplier)
docs.text: Return the contained value, if present, otherwise throw an exception to be created by the provided supplier.

docs.text: Materializes the parallel results and returns an iterator. Allows: for item in Stream(data).parallel(): ...

docs.title: fpstreams.Result
docs.text:
Bases: Generic[T]

A container for a value that represents either a successful result (Success) or a failure (Failure). Replaces try/except blocks in functional pipelines.

docs.title: error property
docs.text: Returns the exception if this is a Failure, otherwise None.

docs.title: failure(error) classmethod
docs.text: Creates a failed Result.

docs.title: flat_map(mapper)
docs.text: If Success, returns the result of applying the mapper (which must return a Result). If Failure, returns the existing Failure.

docs.title: get_or_else(default)
docs.text: Returns the value if Success, or the default value if Failure.

docs.title: get_or_throw()
docs.text: Returns the value if Success, otherwise raises the stored exception.

docs.title: map(mapper)
docs.text: If Success, applies the mapper to the value. If Failure, returns the existing Failure (skips the mapper).

docs.title: map_error(mapper)
docs.text: If Failure, allows you to transform the exception. If Success, does nothing.

docs.title: of(func) classmethod
docs.text: Executes the provided function. Returns Success(value) if it works, or Failure(exception) if it crashes.

docs.title: on_failure(action)
docs.text: Executes action if Failure.

docs.title: on_success(action)
docs.text: Executes action if Success.

docs.title: success(value) classmethod
docs.text: Creates a successful Result.
